urlLink Hey Giddy London! Looks like this could be worth checking out in Sept! I wish I could see it!........... Pet Shop Boys plan free film gig The Pet Shop Boys will unveil their latest project - a soundtrack to the 1925 film Battleship Potemkin - at a free show in London's Trafalgar Square. The film, an account of a sailors' revolt in 1904, has been a major influence on film-makers and artists. The show, which will take place on 12 September, is part of a season of events taking place in the square. In a statement, Neil Tennant and Chris Lowe said the soundtrack would include three new songs. However, it will mainly be a instrumental score. "It's wonderful to be given the opportunity to write a complete soundtrack to this classic film and then to perform it as a free concert in the heart of London," he said. The soundtrack will be orchestrated by German composer Torsten Rasch, who recently launched his live work, Mein Herz Bernnt, based on the music of hard rock band Rammstein. It will be performed by the 26-strong Dresden Sinfoniker. Political dissent Trafalgar Square was chosen because of its long history as the focus for political dissent in the UK. The show is part of Trafalgar Square Summer 2004, a programme of free events organised by Mayor Ken Livingstone. Philip Dodd, director of the nearby Institute of Contemporary Arts, which is producing the show, said: "I'm deeply grateful to the Pet Shop Boys and all the events collaborators for their immediate recognition that Trafalgar Square is the place for re-imagining the past in terms of the needs of the present." The film, directed by Sergei Eisenstein, tells the story of a mutiny on board a Russian battleship, sparked by the crew being given rotten meat to eat. The revolt leads to a riot, which leads to a fleet of battleships being drafted in to destroy the Potemkin. Artists influenced by the film include Francis Bacon, who said he was haunted by the screaming mouth in the film and was inspired to use it in his own work. urlLink

urlLink Just finished reading "Lulu In Hollywood" which is a collection of essays written by the iconic Louise Brooks. What a smart cookie she was. Her astute observations of life in tinsel town during the silent era thru to the talkies is both fascinating and somewhat sad. No wonder she gave it all up in the end. The final chapter she wrote is called "Why I will never write my memoirs" which like her relatively brief film career leaves the viewer/reader wanting so much more. Dear Giddy London, if you are reading this have you ever seen "Pandora's Box" or "Diary of a Lost Girl"? These are defining Brooksian moments that will haunt you forever. urlLink

urlLink At last! Thanks to the new city library I was able to view my first Preston Sturges film. Having read so much about him (and his influence on the Coen brothers) I was thrilled to discover that his reputation as a comic genius was well deserved. What a premise! Hollywood director Joel McCrea hits the road disguised as a tramp in order to gain first hand experience of human suffering for his upcoming flick "Oh Brother Where Art Thou" (see the Coen connection?). On the way he meets up with aspiring actress Veronica Lake (dressed by Edith Head and looking totally amazing!) and the two hit the road with hilarious results. What makes this film even more remarkable is the way in which Sturge's social concerns are so perfectly intertwined with the slapstick comedy. This film charters darker waters as it progresses but ultimately it becomes a filmic ode to the ability of humour overcoming depressing odds. A scene involving a church filled with chaingang prisoners howling with laughter at a Mickey Mouse cartoon is priceless. Can't wait to get my hands on "The Lady Eve" - another Sturges comedy of the sexes starring Barbara Stanwyck. urlLink

I look forward to working with Image's creative, sales and marketing teams to make this series truly special." urlLink From Yahoo news....(trust the Japanese to come up with this doozy..looks like Furby has bitten the dust!!) TOKYO (AFP) - Fans of Hello Kitty will get a chance to realise their dream of chatting with the hugely popular cartoon character later this year with the launch of a hi-tech robot of the feline. The 52-centimetre-high (20.8-inch) robot will be able to recognise 10 people, greeting them and having chats, using phrases such as "It's already lunch time. Have you eaten yet?", according to manufacturer Business Design Laboratory Co. Ltd. Equipped with an ultra-sound sensor and camera, the mechanical Kitty can tell if anybody is approaching. It can call a playmate's name and start chatting by sorting 20,000 patterns of pre-registered conversations and picking phrases it feels are best suited to the occasion. Hello Kitty was created by Tokyo-based firm Sanrio Co. Ltd. According to Sanrio's "biography" of Kitty, the feline was born in London on November 1, 1974. Hello Kitty products are sold in 60 nations and some 50,000 different types of Kitty character goods were sold worldwide during the previous fiscal year to March 2004 alone. Business Design hopes to sell 2,000 robot cats this year, priced at around 400,000 yen (3,710 dollars), by mainly targeting women in their 30s who are among the cat's biggest fans. urlLink

I've started reading a book called "Searching for Kingly Critter" which is all about the history and collectability of those wonderful moulded plastic toys we found lurking within cereal boxes back in the late 60s / early 70s. My heart skipped a beat when I saw the cover of the book featuring the regal Kingly Critter himself. I was obsessed with collecting the Crater Critters, Tooly Birds and the Camel Trains but I actually found King Neptune and his underwater orchestra to be the most fascinating and dreamy. What is more amazing was discovering that these toys were created and manufactured in Richmond Victoria Aust....just across the way!!
